bibl.title: Transcription of letter from Walter Reed to L. O. Howard, January 13, 1900

div1.p: Reed states that the mosquito theory for the propagation of yellow fever is a fact, not a theory. Reed's postscript gives credit to Kean for cleaning measures against the mosquito. [Reed mistakes the year, it should be 1901, not 1900.]

div1.head: Transcription of letter from Walter Reed to L. O. Howard, January 13, 1900
div1.opener:
- Copy -
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba
January 13, 1900. [1901]
Dear Mr. Howard,
div1.p:
I am in receipt of yours of January 5th, and thank
you very much for the card containing Dr. Wolfert's suggestion - I
turned the card over to the Chief Surgeon, yesterday - I enclose a
copy of the order relating to protection against mosquitos - Of
course, you have already heard from Dr. Sternberg of our complete
success in repeating our former observations. The mosquito theory
for the propagation of yellow fever is no longer a theory, but a
well established fact. Isn't it enough to make a fellow feel happy?
Anopheles and Culex are a gay old pair! What havoc they have wrought
on our species during the last three centuries! But with “Howard
and Kerosene”, we are going to knock them out!

closer.seg:
P.S. - Major J. R. Kean, Surgeon, U.S.A., was the Acting
Chief Surgeon of the Division of Cuba, at the time this order was
published, and it was he who drew it up and recommended it to Gen.
Wood. He should have credit for it.
